top_categories.workout_context: Gravel and Tar Classic’s new zealand gravel (70%), paved roads (30%) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Gravel and Tar Classic isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Gravel and Tar Classic rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
At 99 miles, Gravel and Tar Classic punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Gravel and Tar Classic when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Gravel and Tar Classic. Make this intensity feel like home.
Gravel and Tar Classic’s new zealand countryside—rolling hills, farmland and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Gravel and Tar Classic — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Gravel and Tar Classic’s 6,562ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Gravel and Tar Classic — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on new zealand countryside—rolling hills, farmland.
The Norwegian double-threshold method builds the sustained power base for Gravel and Tar Classic — massive training stimulus without the recovery cost of VO2max work.
Every session at Gravel and Tar Classic intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Gravel and Tar Classic’s 99 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Gravel and Tar Classic requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on new zealand countryside—rolling hills, farmland to build confidence. Expect: new zealand gravel (70%), paved roads (30%), rolling hills.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 99 miles of new zealand countryside—rolling hills, farmland in Manawatū-Whanganui, New Zealand.
